message.content:
There is no specific rule in Islam about celebrating birthdays, and it is not mentioned directly in the Quran or Hadith. Some Muslims choose to celebrate birthdays because they consider it a harmless cultural practice that doesn't conflict with their faith, while others may see it as an unnecessary innovation (bid'ah) that can distract from religious obligations.

There are a few different perspectives on celebrating birthdays within the Islamic tradition:

1. Permissible: Many Muslims believe that there is nothing wrong with marking another year of life and spending time with loved ones on their birthday. They view this occasion as an opportunity for family bonding, showing love and appreciation to the person whose birthday is being celebrated, reflecting on personal growth over the past year, and expressing gratitude towards Allah for providing them with good health.

2. Discouraged but not forbidden: Some other Muslims argue that while there's no explicit prohibition against celebrating birthdays in Islam; however, doing so might lead individuals away from their religious duties if many un-Islamic practices or customs typically associated with such celebrations like extravagant parties or inappropriate entertainment enter into Muslim households.

3. Forbidden (haram): A small number of conservative scholars claim that observing one's own or another person's birthday contravenes having proud nature which could steer people from being focused on acknowledging God giving us ample opportunities every day instead of encircling just around special occasions derived externally coming under rules considered Haram unless sanctioned by Almighty explicitly.

It's important to note that opinions regarding birthday celebrations vary greatly among Muslims throughout world depending upon local cultures & traditions hence respecting individual choices plays vital role here avoiding criticism since ultimately intentions matter most when distinguishing between right/wrong actions before Creator keeping ethically acceptable norms only preserving sanctity amongst believers/no-believers alike!
